text: FULL SHOT. The sun, spinning up from behind the dark rim eastern hills, is bleaching the cloudless, morning sky. T is volcanic country, barren, desolate, forbidding. There no sign of life, no sound. Then on a distant hill, a man  appears, to be followed by two others. They walk steadily forward.

MED. SHOT. A dry watercourse threads its way through the in the treeless hills. The sun is not high enough as yet drive night from the canyon. A man appears around a bend; another and still another. They are McCall, Peters and Le clad in prison clothes, hatless, their heads closely crop As Lednov's face comes into a closeup,

LONG SHOT - DOWN ANGLE. A narrow valley lies below. Throu it runs a cottonwood-bordered stream. Smoke curls up out the trees. Horses graze in a small meadow near the creek. From O.O. comes the SOUND of heavy boots crunching across the dry, eroded earth. The three men file past camera to  stop in the immediate F.g. and look down into the valley. They exchange glances and start down.

MED. SHOT - ANGLED THROUGH willows. A bearded man, Cal  Forster, and two young fellows in their late teens squat  beside a campfire eating breakfast. O.s. there is the SOU of movement. Lednov moves cautiously into the scene. He h a revolver in his hand. Forster turns toward camera and fear comes into his  expression. Lednov fires. Forster crumples near the fire. The two boys jump to their feet and reach for rifles. Led fires again and again. McCall and Peters come into the sc both firing revolvers.

MED SHOT - ANGLED ACROSS campfire. On the fire smoulders prison clothes the convicts had worn. Smoke spirals up. I the B.B. Lednov, Peters and McCall, now wearing the cloth of the three Forsters, saddle the horses. CAMERA PANS ARO and ANGLES DOWN. The bodies of Forster and his sons, now  clad in underwear are sprawled by the fire. Forster's arm lies close to the smouldering clothing.

MED. LONG SHOT. Smoke climbs above the trees. Into the  clearing ride the three convicts, to cross it and move  westward. They disappear over the hill. A dust cloud mark their passage. CAMERA HOLDS ON the scene and over the sho comes the MAIN TITLE CARD:
LONG SHOT. A buckboard drawn by two horses comes along th road. Graham, a middle-aged rancher, is driving. As the h trot forward and dust rises above the road, the NEXT TITL CARD is shown.
LONG SHOT - DOWN ANGLE. Graham's buckboard moves down the road toward the clearing, as the TITLE CARDS follow and  change. When the buckboard reaches the creek, the LAST TI CARD is ended.

MED. SHOT. Graham drives the horses through the creek and into the meadow. Through the trees the Forster camp can b seen. Graham glances over, then suddenly pulls on the rei As the horses stop, he twists the reins around the whip s grabs his rifle from under the seat, leaps out and hurrie forward toward the camp.

MED. SHOT. Graham hurries through the trees to stop in ho near the dead men. Then very slowly he moves forward to t smouldering fire. Stooping he lifts Forster's arm away fr the fire, then picks up one of the prison coats and looks it.

MED. LONG SHOT. The surrounding hills are covered with sc pinon pine and mesquite. Graham's buckboard, moving slowl up a hill, passes camera, which PANS WITH it. In the bed, covered by a tarp, are the three bodies. The narrow, one- road climbs easily up the gentle hill. Beyond, a dust clo rises. As Graham's buckboard nears the crest, a surrey ap and starts down. Graham pulls his team into the bank, try to make room for the surrey.

There are four women in the two-seated surrey, which is  heavily loaded with trunks, hatboxes, etc. Mary Wells, th loveliest of the four, is driving. She is more poised, mo self-assured than the others. Her clothes, though a trifl showy, are attractive. She wears a large spectacular hat. Helen Carter, showier, harder and more cynical, sits besi her. In the seat behind are Marcia Paine, placid, younger looking than her years, and Elaine Ross, a striking blond with a pale haunted face. Elaine is obviously ill. Mary i riding the brake and holding the team back.
SHOOTING PAST Graham.
(annoyed) What in thunderation -- (calling) Wait a minute -- stop --

He jerks on the reins and tries to make room for the surr A steep bank is on camera left. On camera right, the road drops off into a gulley. As the surrey comes up Mary rein the team in. The women all look frightened. Graham, tryin to force his team to pull the vehicle up the bank, is too occupied to recognize the women at once. Having made just enough room for the surrey, he turns and looks at the wom
All right -- (then surprised) What are you girls doin' way out  here?
Mary looks ahead at the narrow road and the canyon to her left.
Until you came along we were going  to Sonora.
What do you know about that. Did you  sell your place?
(dryly) Not exactly. They decided gambling  and dancing were bad for people. (pointing) Can I make it?
Depends on how good you drive.
She's a little out of practice.
Graham jumps over the wheel.
Graham reaches the surrey.
(cheerfully) Slide over.
(getting up) I'm slidin' all the way over.
She climbs out. Marcia looks at the narrow space ahead.
(rising) So am I. Come on Elaine.
Elaine leans back against the cushions and shakes her hea
(flat) What's the difference if we fall in  the canyon.
Don't talk like that.
Helen is out on the road now. Mary has moved over and Gra picks up the reins. Marcia gives up and jumps out.
Nothin' to it --
He releases the brake.
-- once you know how. Trouble is,  never was a woman knew how to handle  a team. Shouldn't let 'em loose on  the roads. No disrespect meant, Miss  Wells.
Mary isn't listening. She is looking at the road. Elaine  closes her eyes. Helen and Marcia scurry back out of the  way.
Get up.
Adroitly he drives the surrey past.

featuring buckboard. Helen and Marcia start along the roa past the buckboard. Helen stops and looks at its cargo in horror. She grabs Marcia's arm. The girls look at each ot and hurry after the surrey which has stopped below the  buckboard.
on surrey. Graham jumps out.
There you are. Now take it easy and  you'll be all right.
Thank you, Mr. Graham.
Helen and Marcia hurry up. Marcia motions back.
(aghast) There's -- dead men -- in your wagon!
That's right. You had me so busy I  forgot -- (worried) Come to think of it you better turn  around and drive right back to Aspen.
The women exchange glances. Elaine is sitting up, her eye open.
They were murdered. I found the bodies  on Alder Crick, northeast of here.  Like I said if I was you, I'd go  back, because the men who killed  them might be on this road.
(bitterly) Back to what?
Why, back to Aspen, where you came  from.
As Mary speaks, Helen pushes Marcia into the surrey and c up beside Mary.
Aspen doesn't want us Mr. Graham.  They threw us out.
(distressed) They shouldn't have done that.

We tried to point that out. But there  were some pretty nosey citizens who  wouldn't listen to reason. They said  Aspen had outgrown us. It's all right  to play poker in your own home but  not in a saloon.
(sadly) I knew something would happen when  they started puttin' up fences and  passin' laws.
Mary unwraps the reins from the whipstock.
Goodbye and thanks.
I don't like to see you go.
Mary releases the brake and the surrey starts rolling for
But that's the way it is. The live  ones go out and the dead ones come  in.
The surrey starts down the hill. Graham looks after it, t turns to go back to the buckboard, CAMERA PANNING WITH hi
The town lies in a lush green valley. It is surrounded by meadowland and shaded by cottonwoods, alders and aspen. I the F.g. Graham's buckboard moves fast down hill.

FULL SHOT. In the F.g. a smallish crowd, mostly men and  children idle in the street in front of Mary Wells' Gambl and Dance Hall. The wooden sidewalk is cluttered with tho articles belonging to the women that were too bulky to ge into the surrey. Several women stand on the porch supervi the locking up of the place and the removal of the sign o Mary Wells' name on it. Graham's buckboard rounds a corne at a fast trot. He slows the team to let the people get o of the way.

The team has slowed to a walk. The people give their atte to the buckboard. A boy clambers up over the tailboard, s the cargo and jumps off with a frightened yell. The crowd turns from the dance hall and follows the buckboard leavi the women and their pious male assistants on the porch.

MED. FULL SHOT - ANGLED to include blacksmith shop across the street. Far down the street comes Graham's buckboard  followed by the small crowd. The sheriff's office is a on story wooden structure. Next to it is the general store. front of the blacksmith shop stands a wagon with one whee off. In the corral alongside are eleven blooded mares. Cl Phillips, his brother Steve and the blacksmith are inside the shop. Clay's saddle horse is tethered to the hitching rail beside two harnessed work horses.

ANGLED to include sheriff's office. The blacksmith, Sam E an elderly bent man in a leather apron stands at the forg in which he is heating the rim from the big wheel which l on the table nearby. Clay, a long-legged wrangler in clea but faded work clothes stands near the forge pumping the  bellows and watching his brother, a freckled kid of sixte trying to roll a cigarette. Steve has progressed to the m difficult step, that of licking and sealing the paper. Cl reaches over and takes it from him. He puts the skinny  cylinder in his mouth and Steve lights it for him. The fi third of the cigarette burns with one quick flare.
How does she draw?
A little hot.
Sam lifts the rim to the wheel.
You want to get out of here before  noon, maybe you should lend me a  hand.
Clay, the cigarette dangling from his lips, moves over to the table, picks up a hammer and helps Sam hammer the rim the wheel. Steve stands watching.
Rate you're goin', we'll be here  until winter.
Together they lift the wheel and plunge it into the tub o water. Steam rises to fill the blackened shed.
(amiably grumbling) Account of you, I miss out on the  only excitement Aspen's had for  months.
You're too old to watch such goin's  on.
And I'm too young.
Clay and Sam spin the wheel in the tub.
That's right.
I don't see no sense to makin' people  leave town if they don't want to  leave.

I don't either -- when people are  that good-lookin'. Maybe that's why --  they were too good-lookin'. (philosophically) But there'll be others along to take  their place after a while when this  quiets down. And everything will be  fine until some busybody starts  stirring up trouble.
(mildly) Don't you ever run down?
(to Steve) Some people just have to run other  people's lives. Now take Clay. You  want to amble up the street and see  the fun and what does he say?
(good-natured) You stick to your blacksmithin' and  let me take care of Steve.
From O.s. comes the SOUND of the approaching buckboard an crowd. Steve hears the noise and moves to the front of th shed.

MED. FULL SHOT - Steve's angle. Graham pulls his buckboar up, jumps out and hurries into the sheriff's office. Some kids run up to stand on the porch chattering excitedly.  Members of the crowd straggle up.
ANGLED PAST Steve. Clay comes up to stand beside Steve. S joins them. Steve looks up at Clay hopefully.
We'll both take a look. Anything's  better than listenin' to Sam. (to Sam) Don't forget to shoe the mule.
Clay and Steve exit. Sam looks after them, shrugs disgust and goes back to the wheel.

MED. SHOT - featuring buckboard. The crowd around the wag stands in shocked silence looking at the bodies under the tarp. Clay and steve come up, glance in the buckboard and then at each other. Clay speaks to a man near him.
Who are they?
Don't know. Graham brought 'em in.
The sheriff calls from O.s.
Clay, come up here a minute.

Sheriff Gardner, who has seen Clay through the window, co out of his office on to the porch followed by Jeb Graham a young deputy. In his hand Gardner holds the burned pris jacket. Clay goes up the steps to the porch. Steve follow to the foot of the steps to stand watching. The crowd aro the wagon gives its attention to the men on the porch.
Gardner is neatly dressed with his star hidden under his  coat. His deputy wears jeans, shirt, and leather jacket.
Hello Graham -- Joe -- Mr. Gardner.
Graham's got something to tell you  might interest you.
(motioning toward  wagon) Cal Forster and his sons. Somebody  killed 'em.
He pauses to let that sink in.

You know that cottonwood grove on  Alder Crick? They must have been  eatin' breakfast the way it looked,  sittin' by the fire eatin' breakfast  and when I got there nothin' but  them lyin' dead in their underdrawers.  No horses or guns or grub.
(shocked) Forster never did anyone any harm. (puzzled) But what's that got to do with me? I  came into town from the south.
Gardner holds out the burned jacket.
This was smoulderin' on the fire.
Clay moves over to glance down at the jacket.
I still don't see.
From his pocket, Gardner takes several communications, th through them and passes one over. It is a telegram, of th period.
I got it day before yesterday.
Clay reads it.
BE ADVISED OF ESCAPE OF LEDNOV, PETERS AND McCALL CONVICT

head_text.subj: L.B. GROVE, WARDEN STATE PENITENTIARY NORTON, NEV.

text: BACK TO SCENE. Clay hands the telegram back.
Now are you interested?
Clay nods.
You should be. Maybe Lednov heard  about that Sonora ranch of yours.
Maybe he did.
We're going to look for him. Want to  come along?
I've got eleven horses to get over  the mountains before snow catches me  and covers the feed.
(dryly) And that's more important than finding  Lednov?
Like you said, maybe he knows where  my ranch is. If he does, he'll be  waiting on the porch.
He turns toward the steps.
(with irony) I'll drop the sheriff in Sonora a  line to sort of look around for him.
Clay speaks over his shoulder as he goes down.
Thanks.
As Clay starts away, Steve follows him. Clay doesn't cros to the blacksmith shop. He goes along the sidewalk toward the general store. Steve hurries to catch up with him.
MOVING SHOT. Clay, deep in thought, seems unaware of his  brother at his side.
Who's Lednov?
A man I used to know.
They walk in silence to the General store and Clay goes u the steps and across the porch. Steve follows close behin

The store is a typical general store of the period, selli everything from buggies to baby clothes. In one corner is the postoffice. The storekeeper, Hayes, is unpacking a ca of canned goods, stacking the cans on the shelf. Clay,  followed by Steve, enters. Hayes glances over.
Clay crosses to the shelf where the rifle and shotgun she are kept and takes down a half dozen boxes of 30 30  cartridges.
Forget somethin', Clay?
Shells. How much for six boxes?
Six times six bits. But wait until I  finish this.
Besides Clay, Steve is inspecting a rack of guns.
You might tell a fellow things,  'specially if the fellow's your  brother, seems to me.
Like what?
Steve picks up a rifle, puts it to his shoulder and squin along the barrel.
Like why you're buyin' a whole slew  of 30 30 shells all of a sudden.
I don't want to run short.
You never said this Lednov's name  before, that I can remember.
No call to. That jail looked pretty  solid to me. (pointing to rifle) How's she feel?
Nice.
He pulls the hammer back and snaps the trigger. Hayes com across and takes the gun from him.
You know bettern' to do that, Steve.  Unless you're figurin' on buyin' it.
One he's got, more his size.
But it's leaded up and anyway a 22's  no good for real huntin'. You shoot  a man with a 22 and where are you?
The thing to do is stick to rabbits.
He hands Hayes some money for the shells. Hayes crosses t another part of the store to get change. Clay and Steve, has picked up the rifle again, move over to the counter.
What was he in jail for?
You sure worry that bone. He killed  a fellow.
In a fight?
The other fellow wasn't even lookin'.
This is an awful nice gun. (sighting it) Certainly come in handy when there's  men around who shoot people that  aren't lookin'.
Clay grins. Hayes comes up with the change. Clay takes ou some bills and gives them to the storekeeper.
(points to rifle) I may as well buy it for him.  Otherwise he'll be crying all the  way over the hill.
Steve's expression shows his gratitude and delight. He co up with banter.
You must be plenty worried about  Lednov sneakin' up on us. (hopefully) Think he will?
Yes.
At the ranch maybe?
Maybe at the ranch. Maybe sooner  than that.
(annoyed) Do you have to be so close-mouthed?  I'm your brother. And I'm ridin'  with you. Remember?
(smiling) All right. I'll tell you.
He puts one of the boxes of shells on the end of the coun
Let's say this is the penitentiary.

He reaches down into one of the barrels in front of the  counter. The barrels are filled with beans, nails, dried  apples, hardtack, etc. Clay takes a handful of beans and  makes a trail ending in a little pile.
Here's Alder Crick.
He puts another box of shells on the other side of the  counter.
And here we are in Aspen.
He runs a trail of beans away from "Aspen" toward the end the counter. He runs another trail from "Alder Crick" to  cross the Aspen trail. He puts another box of shells on t far end of the counter.
That's Sonora.
He reaches down without looking and brings up a hardtack.
motioning) Lednov gets out of jail  and comes along here to Alder Crick.  Then goes along here toward the Sonora  road.
Clay drops the hardtack back from where the bean trails c
That's Lednov! (tracing) We come along here.
(pointing) And meet him there.
Unless the sheriff gets too close  and he holes up.
He holds out his hand and Hayes hands him his change.
So let's go.
Steve tucks his gun under his arm. As he passes the count he picks up the hardtack and starts eating it.

MED. SHOT - ANGLED TOWARD Sheriff's office. Up the street men are gathering around the sheriff's office. Some are  mounted. Some are tightening their cinches. Clay and Stev come out of the store to look up the street. Steve munche the hardtack.
(motioning) Sure a lot of guys lookin' for Lednov.
Yeah -- and Lednov's only lookin'  for one man. Me.
Why?
He doesn't like me. What you eatin'?
Lednov.
He glances at the remaining piece of hardtack and then pi it away.
I don't like him.
Clay laughs. As they start up the street, the sheriff mou his horse and, followed by his men, rides forward.

CLOSE SHOT. A woman's hat lies on the rocky earth. It is big, elaborate affair. O.s. there is the SOUND of hoofbea the SQUEAL of a wagon brake and the JANGLE of harness. CA PULLS BACK and ANGLE WIDENS to reveal Clay's wagon coming down a very steep hill. Steve is driving, holding tightly the reins and riding the brake. Seeing the hat, he yells Clay.
Another one, Clay.
Clay rides over and, swinging down, picks it up.

ANGLED DOWN hill. The road twists tortuously down. Near t bottom it swings sharply at right angles into a dry wash. The banks shut out further view of the road. Near where t road turns a trunk lies at the side. It has broken open a some of the contents are spilled out in the dust. Clay ri to it, reins in his horse and looks down. Steve, with  difficulty, pulls the mules to a stop alongside.
featuring trunk and wagon. Clay swings out of his saddle, starts tossing the clothes back in the trunk. Steve jumps down.
They sure must have been travelin'.  This keeps up we can start a store.
Things get tough next winter, you'll  have somethin' to wear.
Steve holds up a petticoat close to his body and grins.
I'd look good doin' the ploughin' in  this.

Clay takes it from him, puts it in the trunk and shuts th lid. Steve helps him hoist the trunk into the wagon bed.  Steve gets back in the seat. Just as Clay is about to mou he stops and picks up a small folding daguerrotype case  delicately ornamented. He lifts his eyebrow, tucks the ca into his pocket, then mounts and starts ahead around the  bend.
Clay's ANGLE. Ahead, off the road in the wash is the surr that passed Graham's buckboard at the fork. Clay spurs hi horse forward.

on surrey. The back wheel is broken and the bed of the su rests on the ground. The horses have been taken from the  traces and stand dejectedly in the hot sun. A blanket is  spread in the scant shade thrown by the surrey. On it lie Elaine and, sitting beside her, is Marcia. A damp cloth i spread across Elaine's forehead. A water bag hangs from t surrey. Elaine's head is pillowed on a dainty satin cushi Helen and Mary have risen at Clay's approach and now stan by the road.
Clay gallops forward to pull up near the surrey. In the b Steve drives the wagon around the bend. Clay dismounts.
Clay drops his reins and hurries up.
Anybody hurt?
No. We came down the hill a little  fast and... (rueful) ...the wheel broke. (hopefully) Can you fix it for us?
Clay bends over Elaine.
What's the matter with her?
(dryly) Too much excitement. How about the  surrey. Can you fix it?
Clay turns from Elaine and gives his attention to the sur
on rear of surrey. In the B.g. Steve pulls the wagon to a stop, jumps off, and comes running over.
Jimininy. You sure were lucky, just  bustin' a wheel.
Helen moves toward Clay. She miles without humor.
(rubbing thigh) You think that'sall we busted -- You  should see...
Clay stops her with a look, goes around, and kicks the  unbroken back wheel. The spokes rattle.
This must have been in the family a  long time.
(dryly) It was a gift from the citizens of  Aspen. I'm Mary Wells.
She looks at him to see if the name registers.
And this is Helen Carter.
I'm Clay Phillips. (motioning) My brother Steve.
Steve tugs at his battered hat.
(shy) Pleased to meet you, ma'am. (brightly) We found your trunk. Were you doin'  the driven'?
I was at first. Then I was hanging  on. (to Clay) Are you going far?
Yes, ma'am.
As far as -- Sonora?
Just about.
Mary and Helen exchange glances.
We're going to Sonora, too, so that  solves everything.
Clay takes the makings from his pocket, starts to roll a  cigarette.
We can ride in your wagon.
Steve looks at Clay hopefully. He likes the prospect of h these lovely women along.
We wouldn't think of asking you to  take us for nothing.
Clay finishes the cigarette, starts to put the makings ba Mary holds out her hand. Clay gives her the makings. Mary speaks as she casually rolls a cigarette.
There's only four of us.
Clay motions to the remuda that grazes in the b.g.
I've got eleven horses.
(proudly) Morgan blood. The beat in Nevada.  Clay and me have a place on the  Toulomne River. We're going to raise  horses like these.
Mary has finished rolling her cigarette. She passes the b to Helen, who starts rolling one.
They won't be riding in the wagon.
(dryly) Did you ever try taking a bunch of  horses over Sonora Pass? It's quite  a job.
You can't leave us here.
Course I can't. I'll give you a lift  to the first ranch.
Helen has finished her cigarette. She passes the makings Steve. He hesitates, looks at his brother and, when he se Clay is occupied with Mary, starts rolling one.
What good is it going to do us to go  to some ranch?
(amiably) You can stay here if you like.
We have to get to Sonora. There are  jobs waiting for us there. We'll pay  you for your trouble.
I'm not running a stage line, ma'am,  and I can't take a chance on losing  the horses.

Steve finishes his cigarette. Again he hesitates, then no wanting to seem young in front of these women he takes a  bold step and lights it. Clay reaches over and takes it f him. Mary watches the byplay.
When you're old enough to smoke,  I'll tell you. (kind) Get the horses started on ahead,  will you, Steve?
Steve, embarrassed and hurt, turns quickly away. Helen lo after the boy.
Afraid it will stop him growin'?
(turning) Let's get your stuff in the wagon.  Like I said, I'll take you to the  first ranch. I wish I could carry  you all the way, but I can't. It's a  tough trip and women would be in the  way.
(dryly) Our kind of women?
(ignores that) You'll have to drive -- except down  hill.
He lifts some things out of the surrey and carries them t the wagon.

Maybe you're going about this all  wrong. Why not try telling him we'll  do the cookin' and mendin' and washin'  for him. That usually works. (then shocked at the  thought) Yeah, but suppose he took us up on  it. Where would we be?
Maybe in Sonora.
She starts around the surrey. Helen follows. Clay bends over Elaine.
What's the matter with her?
(dryly) Too much excitement. Or maybe it's  just the heat. How about the surrey.  Can you fix it?

As Clay turns from Elaine, Marcia joins the other two, th attention on Clay and the surrey. Left alone, Elaine is  suddenly alert and no longer sick. She glances around, th unobserved slides out from under the shade of the surrey.
on rear of surrey. In the B.g. Steve pulls the wagon to a stop, jumps off, and comes running over. Elaine stands fo moment, searching the ground with her eyes.
Jiminy. You sure were lucky, just  bustin' a wheel.
Helen moves toward Clay. She smiles without humor. With t new diversion, Elaine, still unnoticed, starts away -- ba toward where they dropped the trunk.
(rubbing thigh) You think that's all we busted --  You should see...
(sees Elaine) Now where's she goin'? --
(half-turns without  stopping) I -- lost something.
It wouldn't happen to be this...
Elaine stops now and turns as Clay takes the folding  daguerrotype case from his pocket. Elaine, her eyes wide frightened, starts back as Mary takes the case from Clay opens it.
Who's the old folks?
(frantic) Give it to me!

She jerks the case from Mary's hands, snaps it shut, and  stands staring at Mary with a strange mixture of fright,  anger and hysteria. Mary glances around as if to say what did-I-do? To cover the embarrassed silence, Clay kicks th unbroken back wheel. The spokes rattle.
This must have been in the family a  long time.
Elaine glances at him as though he had insulted her, turn and starts toward the blanket again.
(dryly) It was a gift from the citizens of  Aspen. I'm Mary Wells.

She looks at him to see if the name registers. At the sur side, Elaine is abruptly weak again. She leans against it for support. Mareia moves to her as she slides back down the blanket, clutching the case.
And this is Helen Carter.
I'm Clay Phillips. (motioning) My brother Steve.
Steve tugs at his battered hat.
(shy) Pleased to meet you, ma'am. (brightly) We found your trunk. Were you doin'  the drivin'?
Mary and Helen come around the end of the surrey to where Elaine lies. Mary bends beside the sick girl and lifts th cloth from the girl's forehead.
Come on, Honeybunch. We're changing  trains.
The sick girl sits up. She looks around her dully.
A nice, kind wrangler is letting us  ride in his wagon...
Assisted by Mary, Elaine gets to her feet. Mary puts her around her.
...as far as the first ranch. From  then on --
Elaine stops. She looks fearfully up at Helen.
What ranch?
What's the difference?
She tries to lead the girl toward the wagon.
(fierce) Ask him what ranch --
There's plenty of time for that. (sharp) Come on, now. You've got to lie down  out of this sun. Stop worrying. I'll  find out what ranch after a while.
She pulls the girl with her toward the wagon.
on wagon. Clay, in the wagon bed, is stowing his gear in back. Mary, supporting Elaine, reaches the wagon. Seeing girls, Clay reaches down and gently lifts Elaine up. Mary climbs in beside him.
wagon bed. Clay has unrolled a bedroll under the seat whe there is a little shade.
(kind) Stretch out under the seat, Miss.
(desperate) Which ranch?
How's that?
She's worried about where you're  taking us.
As she speaks, Mary helps the girl down under the seat, t rises to face Clay.
(dryly) So am I.
It's a nice place owned by an old  couple named Wyatt.
Elaine as she hears the name. She is shocked.
They'll take you in until you can  make other arrangements.
Clay and Mary. Clay vaults out of the wagon, CAMERA ANGLE WIDENS, he looks up.
So both of you stop worrying.
He turns away and hurries back to the surrey.

FULL SHOT. Dust rises over the road as the cavalcade move forward. Clay, rifle across his lap, rides in front. The  wagon, with Mary driving and Helen beside her on the seat follows. The two horses that pulled the surrey are tied t the tail gate. Then comes the remuda with Steve bringing the rear.
Marcia and Elaine. PROCESS. Marcia sits in the bed of the wagon looking back. Elaine lies under the seat.
Steve. Steve proudly carries his new rifle across his lap He whistles happily as he scans the desert country hopefu for the enemy.

FULL SHOT. Long shadows of the hills lie on the grassy me along the stream that is bordered by cottonwoods and will A knoll overlooks the camp site. The caravan can be seen it halts in the lush grass a few yards from the stream. T girls sit lifelessly on the wagon; they seem too tired to dismount. Then, finally, Marcia helps Elaine to climb sti down. With the exception of Mary they all let themselves  down in the grass. Mary walks to the head of the team and starts fumbling with the harness. on bed. Moonlight falls across the bed. Mary pulls the co up. Helen turns her head.

-- and even if I do learn to read,  what use'll it be? I'm goin' to live  on a ranch!

No.

ANGLED PAST Clay.
Don't go arguing with your teacher.
I'm not, but there's some of it I  don't see any sense to.
There's a lot of things I don't see  any sense to. But make up your mind.  Learn to read or -- (motioning) -- go back and watch the horses.
He touches his horse with his spurs and rides on ahead.
ANGLED PAST Mary. Steve in the b.g. Mary looks after Clay puzzled, wondering. Then she looks over at Steve.
Well, Steve?
(grinning) Now I know what a unicorn is, what  do we do next?

Here the forest has thinned out. The trail climbs a rise, then drops down. Clay jogs along the trail, his rifle acr his knees. As he reaches the edge of the forest at the cr of the rise, he suddenly pulls his horse to a stop, swing around and rides back into the trees. Throwing the reins  over the horse's head, he swings out of the saddle and mo cautiously to the crest of the hill.

Clay's ANGLE. The trail leads down through open country t big meadow ringed with lodgepole pine, and across the mea to start climbing toward another, higher range of hills.  Three horsemen on roans, Lednov, Peters and McCall, are  crossing the meadow slowly.
DOWN ANGLE. Lednov, Peters and McCall as they ride across the meadow.
Clay, as he peers down. He cocks his rifle. The voices of Mary and Steve and the SOUND of the approaching wagon can heard o.s. Clay turns his head.
the cavalcade. Mary and Helen are in the seat of the wago Steve rides alongside.
Clay. He lowers his rifle, waves at them to stop and be q rises and hurries down the hill, CAMERA PANNING WITH him.

MED. SHOT of Lednov as he pulls in his limping horse, ste looking back over his shoulder as though he sensed an  unfamiliar presence. The other two watch him, frowning. T he shrugs and glances down at the bad leg of his mount.
We'll camp on up ahead away. That  leg ain't good...
As they start away, moving slowly toward the trees in the distance...
Clay motions to Mary to stop as he hurries toward the wag Mary reins in the mules.
We're staying here until dark. (motioning) Pull over to the woods. (to Steve) You put hobbles on the horses -- all  of 'em. Get goin'.

LONG SHOT. Clay, in close foreground, stands, leaning on rifle. The sun has set and the valley below is in shadow. There is the silence of dusk. No wind stirs the trees. Th is some light outlining the high mountains -- treeless cr and domes and spires. Clay turns.

Down the hill in the forest, is the wagon. Beyond it the  horses stand. Steve is stretched out on his stomach study his magazine. Helen is sitting on a tarp playing solitair Clay starts down the hill toward the camp.
Clay walks through the trees. As he comes around a big ye pine, he stops suddenly and looks down.
ANGLED DOWN PAST Clay. Mary lies on the carpet of pine  needles, her head pillowed on her arms, her dress pulled  taut across her chest. She is looking up through the tree at the fading sky.

Clay stares down at Mary. She does not look at him. She i aware of his presence, but she doesn't show it. In the so light of dusk she is very lovely. Clay is conscious of he lovliness. He would like to drop down beside her.
Mary. She turns her face to look at him. CAMERA ANGLE WID Clay stands above her, looking down. For a moment their e meet. Clay starts away. CAMERA HOLDS ON Mary.
Where you goin'? Over to the other  side of the street?
ANGLED PAST Mary, who rises slowly. Clay looks back,  hesitates, then crosses to where the horses are tethered starts saddling his mare. Mary moves down toward him thro the trees.
Clay tightens the cinch. Mary moves up to stand beside hi
Are we leaving?
It's too light yet.
He swings into the saddle, pulls the rifle out of the sca and lays it across the pommel.
Better go on back and get some more  sleep. You'll need it later on.
(soberly) You're not going out to look for  them?
No, I'm not. All I want 'em to do is  keep ahead of us -- a long way ahead.  So I'm riding up the line aways to  pick us out a new trail.
He touches the mare with his spurs and trots down the hil He disappears around a bend in the trail.
Mary, in the f.g., is staring after Clay. Helen is watchi her. Steve has risen and walks up behind her. He smiles a her.
Nobody's gonna catch him sleeping.  Don't worry about him.
(turning) Oh, I wasn't worrying. (flustered) I saw him saddling up and thought he  was ready to leave.
She starts down toward the wagon, Steve walking beside he and CAMERA TRUCKING WITH them THROUGH the forest.
(softly) You were worryin'.
Mary glances over.
Sometimes not knowin' how to read  has its points. You can't read books  so you look at people and figure 'em  out.
And you've got me all figured out?
Sure.
They have passed Helen, playing solitaire on the canvas, have reached the place where the grub box stands. Steve  spreads a tarp for her.
I'll fix us somethin' to eat.
Mary sits down. Steve opens the grub box and takes out so plates, tinned food and hardtack.
Like when you were standin' there  looking after Clay. I knew right off  what you were thinking. Because I've  been watching you.
You were supposed to be reading words.
I was doin' both. Here.
He hands her a plate of food, takes another and goes over Helen.
Helen looks up from her card game, takes the plate with a smile.
Thanks, Steve.
He grins at her, turns and comes back to Mary who is watc him.
Better not let Clay catch you waitin'  on us.
Steve sits on the edge of the grub box and picks up his p
Don't pay any attention to him. That's  his way and I've found he's sure  easy to get along with. I don't  recollect him havin' hit me more'n a  couple of times and I guess I had it  comin'.
But you're his brother.
He'll treat his wife just as good.  Maybe better. Ever see him use a  bull snake on the mules like other  wranglers?
Mary shakes her head.
Yes sir, Clay's nice to be around. (the clincher) He don't chew much and when he does  he spits outside.
(dryly) You make him sound wonderful... Go  on. Tell Mary more about him.

Steve looks over at her, embarrassed, a little hurt by he tone. He rises, takes Mary's empty plate and his own and  goes over to the little spring to wash them. Mary looks  sharply at Helen. Helen shrugs. Mary rises and follows St over to the spring.
Steve kneels by the little pool, washing the plates in th run off. Mary stops above him.
She was only teasin'.
(offhand) Oh, sure.
Let me do that.
She kneels beside him. Steve looks over at her.
I like to do things for you. Didn't  you know?
She looks down at the water bubbling up into the little m lined pool.
(softly) I know now.
CLOSE SHOT - DOWN ANGLE. O.s. there is the SOUND of the  cavalcade moving. A wheel passes camera, then another. CA PULLS BACK to reveal the wagon passing in the moonlit  darkness. Mary is driving.
Clay rides into the shot, his rifle ready. The wagon foll Then the remuda with Steve bringing up the rear. Steve al holds his rifle ready. Both men are wary, watchful,  apprehensive.
FULL SHOT - DOWN ANGLE. SHOOTING DOWN THROUGH the leaves a quaking aspen. The cavalcade moves on along the trail.

FULL SHOT. The east is grey with the approaching dawn. Th terrain is treeless, forbidding. Granite crags rise all  around. The trail leads up through a canyon then narrows  along the edge of a cliff. The cavalcade toils forward. C in the lead, stops and waits for the wagon to come abreas
As the wagon comes abreast, Clay dismounts, loops the rei over the tail gate, then swings up into the seat, motioni for Mary to move over. He takes the reins, puts his rifle down in front of him.
Clay and Mary. Helen is sleeping in the bed of the wagon.
Don't you trust me?
Not on this trail, I don't. I've  been over it before. Anyway, you  ought to be pretty sleepy. Why don't  you climb in back.
Mary glances ahead.
I like to see where I'm going.
She picks up the rifle and holds it across her knees.
(dryly) Did you ever care where you were  goin' or where you'd been?
Mary glances over at him wonderingly.
Maybe not! But I want to get there  in one piece.
They ride along in silence for a moment. The trail is rou The jolting wagon throws them together. Their shoulders t
(softly) Why did you change your mind about  bringing us along?
Why do you think?
(soberly) I don't know. I thought I did. Now  I'm not sure. I thought it had  something to do with me.
Oh, it did. It had a great deal to  do with you.
Mary studies him, trying to figure out what he means.
Just how do you mean that?
Clay is busy with driving down the rough road. He speaks  without looking at her.
You know so much about me -- figure  it out.
So that's it -- (he glances over) You think I was making fun of your  girl in gingham.
Helen. She lies in the bed of the wagon, looking up.
I wasn't. And I wasn't making fun of  you or your dream.
She waits for an answer, but getting none, continues.
Of course, maybe I was trying to get  you to do something you didn't want  to do.
Clay and Mary. Clay busies himself with the brake and the reins.
You wouldn't do a thing like that,  would you?
(softly) Yes. But -- that was the other night.  Now -- I don't think I would.
Clay and Mary in f.g. The trail now goes down a slope to river, which boils out of a narrow canyon, then follows t river through the canyon. Clay hands the reins to Mary, t his rifle.
That's the West Walker. Take it easy  now.
Clay swings down. The wagon moves past him. He frees his  horse, swings into the saddle and gallops down toward the canyon.
Mary. She looks after him.
The wagon moves down toward the river. Clay disappears in the canyon. Steve and the remuda follow the wagon.
ANGLED TOWARD mouth of canyon. Clay rides along the trail his rifle at the ready. Now he moves warily, keeping a sh lookout. The canyon is dark, sinister.
The cavalcade enters the canyon.
Clay rides toward camera. The trail curves around a cliff
Clay. He rides around the bend in the trail. He hears  something. He reins the horse in. Some pebbles rattle dow the cliff. He looks up.
The muzzle of a rifle is visible. Clay starts to bring hi gun up.
Hold it!
Clay lets his rifle rest across his knees. He looks up.  Fowler, a well-set-up young man in jeans, blue shirt and  worn jacket and wearing a battered hat, moves into scene.
Clay. He is wary, puzzled as to the man's identity. For a he knows it may be one of Lednov's men.
Clay and Fowler.
What are you doin' on this trail?
Followin' it. Any reason I shouldn't?
SHOOTING PAST Fowler. Into view comes the wagon and the  remuda. Fowler lowers his rifle. He slides down the cliff stand beside Clay.
Clay and Fowler.
My name's Fowler. I'm camped up a  ways.
He extends his hand. Clay shakes it.
Clay Phillips of Aspen. Been havin'  trouble?
Nope. But I don't want any.
Neither do we. That's why we took  this trail instead of the main road,  and drove all night.
You're welcome to use my camp.
He motions ahead, starts walking. Clay rides beside him.
FULL SHOT. The river is beyond the meadow. In the pine fo at the edge of the meadow is Fowler's camp. The cavalcade driving up to the camp. There are two horses tethered in meadow.

MED. FULL SHOT. A tarp is stretched over the camp. There a crude stone fireplace, a rough table and two benches.  Shelves are nailed between the trees. In a small lean-to  there is a bunk with Fowler's bedroll on it. Fowler stand watching Mary and Holen as they get out of the wagon. The horses sproad out across the meadow. Steve and Clay dismo Both unsaddle. Helen, Mary and Fowler exchange glances. T the two women walk toward the camp, which is behind a scr of trees.
Helen and Mary enter the camp.
We might as well start a fire.
Go ahead. (nodding off) Get in training for the pioneer life.  I'm finding the nearest body of water  and climbing into it.
She goes off and across the meadow. Mary looks after her, shrugs and going to the fireplace, takes moss and twigs f the pile and puts them in. Clay, carrying saddle bags and canteens, enters.
Got a light?
He puts them down, goes over to the fireplace and kneels light the moss. Mary has stepped back.

As he lights the fire, the lower portion of Mary's body c into the shot. Clay becomes aware of her closeness. He ri slowly. CAMERA ANGLES UP. Mary is standing facing him, al touching him. They stare at each other without speaking.  Both suddenly move togother. They kiss. There is a SOUND  over shot and they step apart, looking off.
Steve has come into scene and is looking at them. He smil with pleasure and surprise.
(innocently) Want the wagon unloaded, Clay?
(upset) Just the grub box and bed rolls.
Steve nods, smiles at both of them and goes out of scene. Clay and Mary face each other. Suddenly Clay swings aroun and goes out of shot after his brother.
She looks after him, clearly in love, disappointed that t were interrupted. Then she turns to the fire.

Clay and Steve. CAMERA MOVES AHEAD of them as they walk t the wagon. Steve has begun to whistle blithely. Clay look sideways at him. Steve whistles even louder. They stop at the wagon. CAMERA HOLDS. Steve climbs inside and hands do the grub box.
I -- I think it'll be swell.
Clay puts the grub box on the ground. Steve tosses out th bed rolls, then jumps out. He grins up at Clay.
Clay, embarrassed, puts his hand on the boy's shoulder.

When you get older you'll understand  things better. Like women and men.  Just because a man kisses a woman,  doesn't always mean -- well, he can  kiss her and not want to -- have her  around all the time.
Steve watches him, puzzled. His exuberance has gone.
We got a lot to do, you and I. Gettin'  that ranch started and everything.  We've been getting along fine, all  these years. For a while I want to  keep it the way it is.
Abruptly Clay turns and indicates the grub box. Steve wat him.
Take that in and help her get  breakfast, will you?
Steve nods and carries the grub box out of the scene. Cla stares after him. Then he picks up the bed roll and moves around the wagon.
Clay in the f.g. In front of Clay stretches the meadow wi the river beyond. The horses are grazing in the meadow. F can be seen hurrying toward the aspens and alders that sc the river.

MED. SHOT. Here the river moves quietly down. The bank is sandy. Alders and aspens screen it from the meadow. Helen sits on the sand taking off her shoes and stockings. Her  toilet box is beside her. Something on the bank catches h attention, she rises and climbs the bank. Some branches o aspen cover an object. She pulls the branches away, revea a crud, miner's cradle or rocker.
Helen stares down at the cradle. She doesn't know what it is.
(sharp) What are you doing down here?
Helen, startled, turns.
Fowler and Helen. They stare at each other.
(curt) You got no business snoopin' around --
(hard) Me snoopin'? I came down here to  take a bath.
She glances from Fowler to the cradle.
That something I shouldn't see?
(flustered) No. But it's mine and I didn't want  anyone foolin' with it.
Hurriedly he covers it with branches again. Helen watches him, curious, interested.
What is it?
Just a thing I was workin' on.
The way you act, it must be something  pretty secret.
When Fowler doesn't explain she moves on down the bank an sits on the sand.
Go on. Take your bath. I'll beat it.
You wouldn't have a smoke on you,  would you?
Fowler comes over and sits down beside her. He takes [a]  sack of tobacco and papers from his pocket. She reaches f them. He watches her wide-eyed as she rolls a cigarette. holds a match for her.
Thanks.

She turns to the toilet case on the sand beside her, take out a comb. He glances at the box, then reaches over and  from it takes her powder box. He sniffs it. Without  irritation, as though borrowing a toy from a child, Helen takes the powder box from him.
That sure smells good.
I like it.
Up here in the hills, a man gets a  hankering to smell powder.
Then why stay in the hills.
She looks at him then up the bank where the cradle is.
That why?

Fowler hesitates. Helen hands him back the powder box as  matter-of-factly as she took it. He accepts it gratefully again putting it to his nose. Now he looks up at her,  regarding her calculatingly for a moment or two. Their ey meet.
I guess you can keep a secret. That's  a gold rocker. I'm doin' a little  placer mining in a place nobody ever  thought to look for gold before.

He reaches to his throat and lifts over his head a braide loop of rawhide. Attached to the loop is a small, plump,  soft-leather poke. Still holding the powder box, he passe her the poke. She starts to work with the thong.
Look at her -- see her shine. One  week's work.

Helen still struggles with the thong. He takes the poke,  pulls it open, pouring grains of gold into his palm. Hele looks at the shining heap in his hand. Then she takes the poke and pours some of the grains in her own palm. She lo down at it. Her expression is calculating. She looks up a Fowler and then the hard look goes away. She gives him a  soft smile.

CLOSE SHOT - DOWN ANGLE. Mary is asleep in the shade of a pine. She lies on a tarp using a folded blanket for a pil It is very quiet. She stirs, opens her eyes. Her expressi changes. A soft smile plays around her lips as CAMERA ANG WIDENS and we see Clay sitting near her, leaning against bole of a pine. He isn't looking at her. Mary watches him for a moment.
(softly) Roll me a cigarette, Clay.

Clay looks over at her. Then rising he moves closer, squa and rolls a cigarette. He holds it out. She licks it, the puts it in her mouth. Clay lights a match, holds it out. catches his hand and holds the flame to her cigarette.
Thanks.
She still holds his hand. They look at each other.
Why didn't you wake me?
Clay doesn't answer.
You should have. I don't like leaving  things unfinished.
(quiet) Maybe it's better that way.
(intense) You don't mean that Clay.
She holds his hand, smiling up. Clay hesitates, then desi for her is more than he can bear, so he takes her in his  arms. They kiss, holding the kiss for a long while.
They break. She lies looking up. He half lies, half sits  beside her.
(a whisper) Tell me, darling.
What?
What does a man usually tell a girl?

For answer, Clay kisses her again -- hard, ruthlessly. Hi hands crush her shoulders. Mary holds the kiss for a mome then draws back, waiting for him to say the words she wan to hear. His hands pull her toward him. Mary wants the ki but she also wants a declaration of love. She makes one l try to get it.
Tell me -- please --
Clay's grip on her shoulders tightens. She searches his f with a glance -- stares into his eyes -- then pushes him  away and sits up.
Mary. She is hurt by his silence.
All right you don't love me. So let  it go at that.
CAMERA ANGLE WIDENS. Clay's expression hardens. He drops hands from her shoulders.
What did you expect? Speeches I don't  mean?
I don't expect anything. A minute  ago I hadn't cuite waked up.
She stands. He rises to face her.
I'm awake now. Go on. Say what you  want to say. I'll listen.
If it's pretty speeches you want,  you won't be hearing them. Even when  I mean 'em, they don't come easy.
Save 'em for the girl in gingham.  Just tell me I'm not good enough for  you. Go on. Say a woman like me can't  change.
All right -- it's said!
Then let's get started. The sooner I  get to Sonora, the better I'll like  it.
Turning she starts down toward camp.
ANGLED PAST Clay. Below is the camp. Beyond the camp, thr the trees, stands the wagon and Steve is hitching up the  mules. Clay hesitates, then follows.
Mary. Tears form in her eyes. She blinks them away, compo herself with an effort.
MED. SHOT - Helen and Fowler in f.g. Helen sits at one si of the table, Fowler on the other. Helen holds the soft  leather poke. In the b.g. Mary approaches. Behind her com Clay.
You're sure there's more where this  came from?
Plenty more. (motioning) And somewhere up there's the lode,  the rock rotten with it.
Helen pours the gold out in her palm as Mary comes up. Ma stands looking down.
Pretty, isn't it? And all you have  to do is shovel sand into a thing  and the river does the work.
Clay enters the scene and goes over to pick up his saddle bags.
(quiet) Give it back to him. We're leavin'.
Maybe you are. I'm not.
She reaches over and pats Fowler's hand.
I'm stayin' here with Jed.
Mary looks from Helen to Fowler.
(shyly) I figure we'll get along just fine.
Well cheer, why don't you? No more  responsibilities, Mary. Marcia --  Elaine -- me -- all taken care of.  Down there feeding horses and raising  kids, you won't have a thing to worry  about.
Mary stands looking down at Helen. Lovingly Helen pours t gold back in the poke.
I'm not raising horses or kids for  anybody. I'm opening the slickest  gambling house in California with a  crystal chandelier, the biggest you  ever saw --
Clay, saddle bags in hand, straightens. Mary directs the  rest of the speech at him.
-- Gaslights and a dance floor and a  big bar. Cash registers with bells  and a couple of boys with armbands  just to keep 'em ringing. What do  you think of that?
Sounds fine. Only that isn't how  it's going to be.
Helen juggles the poke in her hand.

I'm sure of this. But not of you. (shakes head) You won't open any joint. I've been  watching you change. You're mad now  and you think you can change back.  But you can't. You'll end up making  beds in a boarding house.
(furious) That's it then.
(the master) That's it. She's staying with me --  for keeps.
Steve has entered the camp and is standing looking at the open-mouthed. Mary moves over to Fowler and holds out her hand.
If there were more men like you,  there wouldn't be so many of us.
Thanks.
It's nice to meet a man who doesn't  want to own a woman from the day she  was born. I never had the luck. The  only kind I've run into were tramps  or dirty-minded hypocrites.
Clay moves up beside Mary.
Clay, Mary and Fowler.

(to Fowler) She's aimin' at me, but her aim's  bad. (to Mary) Want to know why I changed my mind  about bringing you? Because I talked  to Elaine -- because I was afraid to  leave you with decent people, that's  why. And you'll open your joint all  right. You wouldn't fit anywhere  else.
He moves on past her, motions to Steve.
Let's round up the horses.
Steve hesitates.
(sharp) Come on -- we don't want to keep the  people in Sonora waiting.
He stalks away, followed by Steve. Mary turns and looks a him.
Mary. She wants to break windows.
Mary, Fowler and Helen. Helen is staring at Mary. She cro to her and puts her arm around her shoulders.
Mary, Honey. I talked too much, like  always -- he thinks you told Elaine  the things I told her.
(furious) I don't care what he thinks.
Mary throws her arm off and moves after Clay and Steve. H looks at Fowler and shrugs.
the wagon. As Mary hurries up to stand by the tail gate,  Clay and Steve, now mounted, spur their horses and start  across the meadow.
Mary. She stares after them, raging. Then she glances at wagon.

Mary in f.g. The mulos stand in their traces, waiting. Ma makes up her mind what to do. Climbing into the bed, she  heaves out pack saddles, bed rolls, ropes, etc. Clay and  Stove can be seen in b.g. riding down toward where the ho graze.
ANGLED TOWARD camp. Into the scene come pack saddles, bed rolls. Helen and Fowler, in b.g., walk toward the wagon.

wagon. Mary straightens, looks off, then climbs into the  seat and picks up the reins and the whip. She lashes the  mules with the whip. CAMERA ANGLE WIDENS. The mules jump gallop off. Fowler and Helen come into the scene.
the wagon, pulled by the galloping mules, is disappearing a cloud of dust.
the meadow. Clay and Steve have almost reached the horses Steve turns.
Clay -- look!
Clay swings around.
their ANGLE. Mary drives the wagon around a bend in the t
ON Clay. He glances after Mary, then reins his horse arou and gallops after her, CAMERA PANNING WITH him.

MOVING SHOT. Mary drives the wagon along the trail. Ahead beyond the river, the mountains rise. The river is runnin bank full. The trail leads down to a rocky, dangerous ban Mary pulls the mules in at the bank.
Mary. She looks toward the river. She is frightened, abou to abandon the whole foolish enterprise. She glances back
FROM Mary's ANGLE. Clay gallops around a bend in the trai
Mary. She looks in Clay's direction, then turns and stare at the river.

ANGLED PAST Mary. She makes up her mind to go through wit it and lashes the mules with the whip. CAMERA ANGLE WIDEN The mules balk when they reach the river. Mary lashes the again. They jump forward into the torrent.
Clay gallops toward the river. Steve comes around the ben in the trail.

the river. The mules flounder, start swimming. The curren catches the wagon. It starts drifting downstream. Mary wh the mules. They swim, the current pulls them. Then the wa goes over. Mary is thrown into the water. The mules kick  themselves free and swim to the other bank. Mary goes und comes up and starts swimming desperately. Clay rides into the SHOT. His mare hesitates at the bank. Clay spurs her she plunges in. Mary's belongings can be seen floating do the river.
Clay swims his horse toward Mary who is floundering in th stream.
Mary. The current sweeps her against a rock. Stunned -- s goes under.
Clay swims his horse to her, reaches down and lifts her u in front of him.
Clay's horse, with the double burden, fights her way out the stream and scrambles up the bank to stop on level gro

Clay and Mary. Clay, his expression anxious, stares down the stunned Mary. He swings out of the saddle, holding he tenderly to him. The brush with death has made him realiz how much she means to him. Gently, he puts her down on th sand, stoops beside her.
Clay and Mary in f.g. Steve swims his horse across and ri up the bank to dismount near them.
Mary --
Mary opens her eyes and sits up
(anxiously) Are you all right?
Mary is humiliated, bedraggled and wet, still angry and  fighting back tears.
(sharp) No, I'm not all right. I'm soaked  and I hit myself against that rock.
(nettlod at her tone) I suppose that's my fault.
Mary gets to her feet. CAMERA ANGLE WIDENS. Steve stands the b.g. She looks out at the river.
(wailing) All my clothes --
That's right -- worry about your  clothes --
to include wagon in river. Clay, suddenly furious, points the wagon.
What about my wagon. Of all the crazy  fool things to do. You lose a man's  wagon because you're stupid and then  yell about your clothes.
This is the last straw. Mary turns her back, digs into he stocking and pulls out some bills. She hands them to him.
For the wagon.
Clay looks at Mary, then down at the money.
Go on, take it. Then you can't spend  the rest of the trip expecting to  get paid.

(furious) There won't be any rest of the trip.  Over the hill is a stage road and  when we hit it you get dumped into  the first stage that comes along. So  keep your money. You'll need it for  the fare. I'm fed up with you. I was  fed up with you before we started.
He turns and sees Steve standing scowling at him. He take the rest of his anger out on Steve.
Don't just stand there. Go on back  and get the packs on the horses.  We've lost all the time we're going  to because of a woman.
Clay strides over to his horse and swings into the saddle Steve stands looking at Mary.
Come on. Didn't you hear me?
As he plunges his horse into the stream:

FULL SHOT - the lower ford. Where the main road crosses t river, it flows gently, with sand banks on either side. T horsemen appear around a bend in the trail and ride down the riverbank. They are Lednov, McCall and Peters. Lednov horse is limping badly. They ride into the river.
The horses swim to shore and flounder up the bank, Lednov horse last. As the horse starts up the bank Lednov sees  something o.s. and reins the horse in.

FROM Lednov's ANGLE. A piece of clothing floats down the  river. Lednov rides down the bank into the water. He reac down awkwardly and gets the piece of clothing, then turns and rides back up the bank.
The two others have turned and are watching him. He rides to them, holding out one of Mary's undergarments.
We got company. Female company.
(looking at the garment) Yeah, we sure have.
He turns to scan the river.
Mary's trunk comes floating by. The three men look at eac other, then Lednov turns his horse and starts up the bank the river. The others follow.

location: PEAKS OF THE SIERRA NEVADA MOUNTAINS

text: EXTREME LONG SHOT. The long pine-covered approaches, and glistening summit; the early snow covering the rocks with thin layer of white. CAMERA PANS DOWN FROM the heights of the mountains, TO the narrow trail that winds among the t Clay passes, and behind him the pack-horses and the romud Following the remuda comes Mary. She is dressed in a pair Steve's pants and wears one of his shirts under her own c
Mary, as she swings with the movement of the horse. She i tired. She wears no makeup. But she looks as unaffectedly beautiful as we have ever seen her.
